title: Ask Chris Black: What Are Your Thoughts on Watches?
text:
8 items in this article Photo: Chris Kennedy

If you’re looking for the most powerful hair dryer or the handiest chef’s knife, those things can be easy enough to find. Other objects of desire are a little more taste-based. What’s the next status water bottle or hand wash, for instance? Chris Black (he’s a partner at brand consultancy Public Announcement) is here to help in the form of a regular column. If you have a burning question about the next fanny pack or Noah rugby shirt, drop us an email with the subject line “Ask Chris” at strategist@nymag.com.

What are your thoughts on watches? Now that I graduated from college and I’m moving to the city, I’d like to purchase one that I can wear anywhere from work to out at night. Rolexes are a little pricey me for right now, and I hate smartwatches, so looking to find something tasteful and high-quality that won’t totally break the bank.

I have had a long journey with pricey wristwear. In my early 20s, in an attempt to seem rich and grown (SMFH), I bought a Panerai (before the bankers ruined them). It was a little gauche for me and ended up sitting in a drawer. So I sold it and got a Rolex GMT Master II, which also sits in a drawer. Watches just aren’t for me. That said, they can be so so chic.

Cartier Tank Solo Watch I would definitely advise buying vintage, as your dollar will go further. A timeless, previously owned Cartier Tank never goes out of style and can be had for less than $3,000. Good enough for Alain Delon and Princess Diana, good enough for you. Then there’s the Rolex Air King, which is a little more pricey. This one from 1973 would do the trick. Initially produced for the British Royal Air Force and its pilots, it will serve you well at the office or a corner table at Frenchette. And a lot of guys I know love Omega. This vintage Seamaster has a cool rugged look and is one of the most important dive watches ever made. Jump into the Atlantic without worry! $2,120 at The Real Real Buy

Swatch Metal Knit Quartz Resin Watch If you want something new and crushingly simple, the Swatch Skin Classic is the perfect choice. A truly “less is more” piece of wristwear, it says I am smart and successful, but don’t need a piece of high-end wristwear to prove it. $120 at Amazon Buy $120 at Amazon Buy

I just bought a new 13” Lenovo Yoga laptop, and I’m looking for a sleek, classy sleeve or case to protect it. What’s the best way to protect my laptop without looking like a dweeb?

First of all, what is a “yoga laptop”? I have never seen those two words next to each other. Laptop sleeves are a tough category since most of them are over-designed and scream … “dweeb.” I’m lucky enough to have a plain black leather one that a friend made for me almost ten years ago, and it’s held up beautifully. A search for “laptop sleeve” returns mostly the bad stuff, so the key here is to search for “document holder” — it’s fashion-speak for two pieces of leather connected by a zipper that can hold something.

Burberry London Check Digital Case Show your love for British heritage with this one from Burberry with the brand’s classic check, but in a darker hue. Timeless! $690 at Farfetch Buy

Bottega Veneta Intrecciato-Leather Document Holder This document holder from Bottega Veneta is absolutely beautiful and looks like a clutch. If you are rich, this is the only option. $1,900 at Matches Fashion Buy

Thule Gauntlet 3.0 13" MacBook Pro Retina Sleeve $54 (was $60, now 10% off) If you need something more durable, this Thule option, a more traditional laptop case, is cool because it’s rugged; purely functional, and designed to take a beating, it features “superior edge protection,” which sounds dangerous. Namaste. $54 at Amazon Buy $54 at Amazon Buy

I recently proposed to my longtime girlfriend, and we are now beginning to plan for our wedding next fall. We haven’t decided if it will be black-tie or not, but I’m wondering what tuxedo or suit you would recommend I wear for the big day (depending on what we choose)? Feel free to provide a full head-to-toe look.

Let me say this, chief, no one likes black-tie. It’s fussy, and a lot of men in your life do not own a well-fitting tuxedo. But, if you do decide to go that route, let’s do it right. I actually wore a black seersucker Thom Browne shorts tuxedo to the MTV VMAs last week and am itching to wear it again! Anyway, let’s give you a full look.

The Row Black Mark Slim-Fit Silk Grosgrain-Trimmed Escorial Wool Tuxedo It’s your big day, no expense can be spared: That’s why you are wearing The Row. Supple, luxurious fabric will help you feel confident and relaxed even when all eyes are on you and your bride. This tuxedo is a thing of beauty. It’s retro in the best possible way, double-breasted front and peak lapels, subtle and slim-fitting. Perfection! $5,795 at Mr Porter Buy

The Black Tux Double Breasted Tuxedo If you don’t have upward of $6,000 to spend, a good trick is to rent a tux from The Black Tux, which is a great service that I actually used when serving as a groomsman in my sister’s wedding. The process couldn’t have been easier. They even cover tailoring. But do splurge on the shirt, tie, and shoes (see above). It will help bring the rental tux up a notch. You will look great and you might even have a little cash leftover for your first house. From $125 at The Black Tux Buy

If you’re just looking for some basics, might we suggest this Chris Black Starter Pack — his favorite white T-shirt, jeans, sneakers, socks, gym shorts, etc.

description: Our resident Cool Guy Chris Black weighs in on the best wedding tuxedoes, non-awful watches, and laptop cases that won’t have you feeling like a dweeb.
